 RUSSIAN FEDERATION LEGAL REFORM PROJECT TECHNICAL ANNEX INTRODUCTION 1.1 Fundamental change is well underway in Russia today. Since 1992, price and trade liberalization, mass privatization. the development of a private financial sector has already led to the emergence of new groups of entrepreneurs and new sources of wealth in the private sector. However, economic reforms will not flourish and private investors and entrepreneurs will not prosper without a legal system which can effectively protect private property, defend economic rights against infringement, and establish a secu,e environment for investment and market relations. The extent of institutional change in Russia today is not yet sufficient to ensure the continued efficient allocation of resources in the emerging market economy. vWhich critically depends on the ability and willingness of market agents to undertake independent economic activity. 1.2 Current legal protections available under the Russian legal system are weak and inadequate. This is, to a large extent, a legacy of the policies of the former socialist regime. For seventy years the existence of property rights outside the state was barely recognized and independent economic activity was discouraged. Executive bodies and other state organs frequently failed to implement laws and almrost routinely issued legislative acts which contradicted laws. In addition, in the economic sphere, the dispute resolution system was employed to carry out the central plan rather than to enforce property rights, and the judicial system offered very few protections to citizens against administrative discretion of executive agencies. Thus, in areas relating to private economic activity, the legislative framework has had to be developed in great detail in order to overcome the inherent systemic prejudices against market activities, the implication that certain activities were legally prohibited, and that citizens were to be left open to administrative abuse. The means of securing legal protection and remedies for infringement of economic rights, both in substantive and procedural terms, have in many instances proved to be barely functional. What has emerged in Russia is an imperfect legal system that significantly impedes economic transactions. Weak contract enforcement has resulted in the inclusion of risk premiums in the pricing of goods and services. Business people feel that the laws are unreliable and contradictory. This perception has contributed to fraud, sometimes on a massive scale, and corruption, the costs of which are borne by the entire society. Last but not least, the inefficient judicial system fails to provide speedy resolution of disputes and thus undermines the rule of law. This promotes the use of illegal channels to protect property rights and to resolve competing claims. 1.3 The legal system comprises only one of many institutions which frame an economic system, but it is arguably one of the most important. The legal system is the most formal of economic and social constraints. Informal constraints on economic behavior are formed very much in relation to the existing legal system. Moreover, institutional development is premised on a feedback effect: poor institutions will lead to the emergence of organizations which are efficient at seeking rents, or creating monopolies, which in turn will be interested in perpetuating the institutions which have favored them. One of the key factors to a rapid and sustainable transition to the market lies in accelerating the process of legal reform in Russia. 1.4 For the past five years the Russian legislature and Government have kept up an impressive rate of legislative output which has begun to fill many of the initial gaps in the legislative framework regulating the economy. However, even as the Goverrnment and the legislature work to fill these gaps

Just as Soviet laws do not provide an adequate framework for market transactions, other legal institutions-such as the judiciary, the legal profession, and information systems-are having difficulty in responding to the new demands placed upon them. Given the explosive increase in the number of economic transactions taking place in Russia today, key legal institutions are falling behind in their ability to regulate the marketplace. The result is eroding faith in the link between law and the effective functioning of a market economy. Survey and focus group data point to the following: * Laws are not perceived to be the basis of economic relations; a People are overwhelmed by the volume and flow of new laws and regulations, and have no way of accessing accurate information about the laws that govern business and economic behavior; * People are not accustomed to seeking legal counsel, nor do they feel themselves qualified to assess the quality of legal counsel they might get; and * Legal institutions ranging from judges, attorneys, and legal officials are held in low esteem and are underutilized by the population-the result being that people often turn to extra-judicial (and frequently illegal) means of resolving disputes. The task of continuing to generate new legislation for a market economy still looms large. But the best drafted laws, if people perceive the laws to be not implemented or enforced, cannot lead to a properly functioning market economy. A program for legal reform in a transition economy such as Russia, therefore, must aiso be equally focused on the effort to build institutions which restore, or develop, the readiness of people to abide by and uphold the law. 1.5 A program supporting legal reform in the transition to a market economy has pzeliminarily been identified by the Government as including, among others, continuing tofill the gaps in the legislative framework, including at the regional level; ensuring public access to transparently and systematically organized authoritative laws and regulations; improving the education of lawvers and awareness of the public about and other members of the legal profession; and beginning to reform the judicia,y. Each one of :hese tasks is a long-term effort involving considerable resources. However, these tasks cannot easily be delinked from one another. One cannot begin to encourage the public to turn to law on resolving economic disputes if the courts are not adequately staffed to handle cases efficiently. Nor can the country cap.ure the full value of well-drafted laws if the laws are not readily accessible to the public for them to begin abiding by them. Finally, seeking legal counsel will be a frustrating exercise for people who finr' hat law school graduates have had little expertise in law touching upon economic transactions and training ili-suited to the practice of law.

INSTITULIONAL SETTING 2.1 The central objective of legal reform for the economic transition is to create a framework of laws and legal institutions that support and regulate the range of economic activities which make up a market. The discrete tasks associated with legal reform in the transition as discussed below range from the creation of a legislative base, increasing the availability of information about and understanding of the law, the strengthening of the judiciary, and the growth and development of the legal profession. The establishment of a legal framework for a market in a transition country like Russia, however, cannot succeed if it cannot simultaneously begin to legitimize a larger, more authoritative role for law in the governance of society. Legal reform for the economic transition in a country like Russia is integrally linked to the legitimation of law as an organizing principle in society, rather than as an instrument of political power. This in turn cannot be accomplished by fiat-rather, law must be shown and proven to be of value in organizing economic and social transactions and in protecting individual citizens and entrepreneurs against the misuse of administrative discretion of the agencies of executive power. Under these circumstances, the passage of new laws appropriate for the market which are not effectively promulgated, implemented, or enforced is not enough. Nor will improvements in the implementation and enforcement of laws which are still oriented to a planned economy be sufficient. On the contrary, either approach can prove to be harmful to the credibility of law, and ultimately to the sustainability of legal reform in a transition economy. 2.2 In the years since the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the Russian legislature and Government have succeeded in filling many of the initial gaps in the systemic legislative framework by passage of numerous laws, decrees and regulations affecting market activity. There remains, however, the far greater problem of basic institutional development in the legal sphere. Both Governmnent officials and outside observers have concluded that the sustainability of legal reform for the transition depends criticall, upon the creation and development of key legal institutions. These tasks include, among others, strengthening of the law making process (the process by which the country drafts, considers and adopts its laws and regulations at federal and regional levels and coordinates these efforts); improvement of legal information systems (which make systematically and transparently organized laws and regulations widely accessible to government at all levels, to legislators, judges, the legal profession and the public); developing legal education and training (to produce competent lawyers, judges and other legal officials required to defend and enforce the rights of market agents and to educate the public about its newly established economic rights); and reforming the judiciary (the best laws, if inappropriately or inadequately enforced, can neither defend the private sector against encroachments by the state, nor against the exercise of monopoly power in the marketplace); and establishing expeditious and efficient alternative dispute settlement mechanisms which complements the official adjudication of disputes. 2.3 Institutions are almost never built completely anew. Successful legal reform in Russia will depend on the extent to which new institutions can incorporate, if not co-opt, elements of actors functioning within existing institutions. In developing a legal framework for a market economy, the Russian authorities have had to work with existing legal traditions and institutional structures which are, at best, marginally suited to supporting market activities. In the legislative area, for example, although in many cases systemic overhauling of the existing codes of law would be simpler, such instances have so far been limited to the adoption of the Constitution, and the first two parts of the Civil Code. Working in the context of existing traditions and institutional structures, moreover, has tended to preserve the power of organizations and interest groups which have a vested interest in preserving existing institutions. While in many cases there is potential for adapting existing codes and statutes to the demands of the market, some institutional processes have to be fundamentally changed to facilitate this incremental process of legal reform. These institutional distortions, in fact, have until recently prevented reform efforts from being focused and coordinated among the various government agencies.

In the last two and a half years, since the adoption of the December 1993 Constitution, the number of laws passed by the Parliament has grown exponentially. Notwithstanding the breakneck pace of legislative activity, the task of creating a legal framework for the market is far from complete. Obsolete laws and legal and regulatory gaps and overlaps abound in areas of crucial importance for effective functioning of a market, including real property law, taxation, and bankruptcy. Moreover, the need to keep pace with the rate of both the macroeconomic and structural changes taking place in the Russian economy today has led to the passage of imperfect laws, such that many laws which have already been adopted are often not consistent with each other and even within themselves and need to be modified or amended. Both the task of completing the legal basis for transition to a market, and of beginning the internal harmonization and codification of the accumulating large mass of new legislation must be continued to preserve and develop the role of legal institutions in regulating the market. 2.7 International technical assistance in this context cannot, of course, substitute for a policy commitment to pass the laws necessary to support the continued development of a market economy in Russia. It cannot serve as a direct substitute for improved coordination within the government. Nor can it significantly reduce the amount of work associated in the drafting of a particular piece of legislation. It can, however, inform the process of legal drafting in Russia with comparative experience, with knowledge of models of how particular laws or combination of laws can be implemented and enforced in practice. At the same time, any technical assistance in this area must be provided within an institutional framework which does not exacerbate the task of internal coordination-full government ownersltip of the mechanisms by which this technical assistance is received and allocated among government entit'es involved in the legal drafting process will be critical. A final issue in the institutional setting for legal drafting in Russia concerns the federal nature of the polity. Federalism in Russia is as yet very new, with subjects of the Federation only now beginning to adopt their own laws. Giv -n the certralized nature of policy making in the pre-reform period, regional authorities have had no meaningful experience in legislative drafting. As yet, the legislative basis for jurisdictional separation is incomplete. Several federal agencies are directly involved in the development of databases and electronic distribution systems for legal information. The most important among these are databases maintained by the MOJ, GGPU, and the High Arbitrazh Court. The MOJ Scientific Center for Legal Information (NCPI) is meant to service the needs of the system of the MOJ and its regional centers (in each of the 89 subjects of the RF) and the courts of general jurisdiction, while a more limited electronic version is available for the public on commercial terms. The GGPU has contributed to the STC "Systema" database which is designed to be both an authoritative standard as well as a source for updated pieces of federal legislation both for government entities and the public. Although a high level working group, Federal Commission for Legal Informatization, has been established by a presidential decree to develop a framework and design for effective dissemination of legal information, the level of consensus and coordination it can generate remiains to be seen. In addition, a number of private sector providers of legal information operate in Russia. Among these are companies such as Konsultant and Garant that are becoming an important source of timely information (although not always accurate), mostly for commercial users. However, no clear policy has yet emerged on the appropriate relationship between the public and private sectors. In this context, the project seeks not to build a comprehensive legal information system, but to define the appropriate role for public sector investment in this area, the feasibility of such a system and its relationship to a number of agencies and ministries involved in this area, and the way in which such a system might appropriately interact with emerging private-sector providers of legal information. 2.10 Over the last several years, the Russian Parliament and executive agencies have issued a massive amount of legislative enactments. Currently, there does not exist any systematized way of organizing legislation. Enactments are published in daily newspapers and, with a significant time lag and in insufficient quantities, in official gazettes. These publications are only chronological. Therefore, in researching a legal issue at any given time, one must look through years of chronologically published official gazettes (if available). This situation forces most official bodies, courts, and private practitioners to create their own classification systems of legislation-systems that allow them to readily access the enactments they need. Such a system in which each agency has to create its own organization for legislation is very inefficient. The project will provide technical assistance to assess the current classification systems existing in Russia and recommend the design of a classification system that can be introduced nation-wide, in both written and electronic form. Another endemic problem in Russian legislation over the last several years has been frequent contradictions and overlap among different pieces of legislation. The project will provide technical assistance to develop methodology on how to "codify" Russian legislation, once the classification system is developed, i.e., summarize and index all pieces of legislation on any given topic and then, through legislative action eliminate overlapping pieces of legislation ("svod zakonov"). International technical assistance in this area can be particularly useful due to successful recent experience with codification in countries such as The Netherlands. 2.11 Legal education. Radical changes in the substance and scope of law and changes in the demand for professional legal services have in many ways overwhelmed the system of professional legal education. There are not nearly enough legal educational institutions available to provide training to a sufficient number of lawyers to satisfy both private and public sector demands. Some 60 schools are accredited to provide legal education, but they are hampered by the inability to provide legal education appropriate for the practice of law in a market economy. Curricula are outdated, with little coverage of legal issues related to the needs of a market economy. Professors who are able to teach economic law courses are in extremely short supply. Many law schools are not familiar with teaching materials or methods geared towards the development of skills to practice, rather than to study, law. The increased

Currently, there are wide gaps in the Russian population's knowledge of the concept of rule of law, as well as in efforts to educate the public about such principles. Baseline research (a summarv of which is in Appendix H) indicates that the Russian public does not yet see the law as the primary framework for economic and business relationships. The vast majority of people fundamentally distrusts all law enforcement agencies, including the courts. Media content analysis indicates that media coverage of legal topics does little to address this problem, pointing to the fact that most Russian journalists lack the basic knowledge, understanding, and research skills required to analyze and write about law as its functions in a market-based economy. Nor are legal texts, commentaries or basic texts readily available for the general public. At the same time, studies show that the Russian public is aware of the unsatisfactory condition of the legal system and would like to make better use of existing legal mechanisms to meet its business and other needs. This points to the conclusion that broad- based efforts to increase public understanding and use of law as the basis for economic and business activity could bring highly favorable results. Baseline research also indicates that a public information campaign tightly focused on the role of law in regulating and organizing market transactions would be accepted by a large majority of the public groups encompassing a wide range of political and social opinions. The project will focus its technical assistance on mass media education, public education about law in secondary schools, and on public information campaigns about alternative dispute resolution. 2.13 Judicial reform. The Russian judicial system faces two challenging tasks. First, the economic reforms accompanying the transition to a market-based economy have resulted in a manifold increase in market participants and transactions. This has placed new burdens on the formal adjudicating system, especially in view of the increasing reliance of the business community and individuals on newly sanctioned property and contractual rights which require enforcement by an effectively run and fair judicial system. Second, the 1993 Constitution of the RF formally established the judiciary as an independent branch of government. Russian judges, who in the past merely fulfilled the role of civil servants, are now faced with the difficult task of building up their independence in adjudicating disputes, adjusting to their new role as neutral arbiters in civil matters, and assuming the role of protecting the legal rights of citizens vis-a-vis state agencies in a variety of criminal and administrative matters. Partly in response to the challenges posed by the above and partly because of the legacy of Soviet institutions, a complex and convoluted structure of judicial institutions has emerged in Russia today. It includes the Constitutional Court, three instances of courts of general jurisdiction, and three instances of arbitrazh (commercial) courts. There is no unified or even similar structure for administering and financing the various courts. The Constitutional Court is directly funded from the federal budget and administered I/ In 1995 state institutions admitted 33,000 students and private institutions 25,000.

The first two instances of courts of general jurisdiction are administratively and financially subordinate to the MOJ; their budget is channelled through the MOJ. Their third instance, the Supreme Court of the RF, is funded directly from the federal budget and administered independently. This makes the courts of general jurisdiction suffer from a lack of institutional leadership. Also importantly, it makes the first two instances of the judiciary beholden to the MOJ, an executive agency which has a vested interest in maintaining the status quo and little incentive to champion the cause of judicial reform which would eventually lead to pressures to institutionalize the independence of the judiciary by severing or limiting MOJ's links with the courts. The arbitrazh courts (which are transformed from the former 'state arbitrazh'-a quasi-judicial executive agency vested with resolving disputed among state-owned enterprises) are fiscally and institutionally better off than the courts of general jurisdiction and frequently are better staffed. There is a substantial jurisdictional overlap between the two court systems in economic disputes. The arbitrazlh courts resolve economic disputes only among judicial entities and among registered individual entrepreneurs. If one of the parties is a physical person, the same dispute falls under the jurisdiction of general courts. The High Arbitrazh Court which administers all three instances of arbitrazh courts and receives a direct federal budgetary allocation is not particularly open to the idea of merging this dual-track system. 2.14 Judicial reform, including the introduction of structural changes, remains high on the reform policy agenda. In the March 1996 Congress on Legal Reform, President Yeltsin underscored the need to address judicial reform including the creation of a judicial department for the courts of general jurisdiction, this would integrate the three instance system and limit the role of the MOJ vis-a-vis the courts. In the current legislative and institutional context of the judiciary, external assistance can be effective only in a limited number of areas. Therefore, the project seeks to address several discrete areas of judicial reform. It will finance technical assistance to fill some of the gaps in the rules of procedure; to train judges of general jurisdiction and arbitrazh courts; a study of the courts of general jurisdiction to analyze ways in which to improve court administration and case management; and judicial workshops which could lead to the development of professional and institutional consensus for judicial reform among the judiciary. 2.15 Alterative dispute resolution. Private sector participants in both developed and developing countries often seek alternatives to having their disputes adjudicated through official judicial bodies. Alternative forms of dispute resolution (ADR), are receiving increased recognition world-wide as an integral compoaent of law-based societies. For example, even in extremely litigious societies, such as the United States. relatively few contract violations are resolved in formal courts of law. Mediation, arbitration, conciliation, informal negotiations, and mini-trials complement the official adjudicating bodies and often pro-ide quicker and less expensive solutions to a range of legal problems. As a complement to reforming the state-run judicial system and strengthening its institutional capacity, the GOR is interested in the development of quasi-judicial, alternative forms of dispute resolution. ADR is perhaps even more important in countries with poorly developed legal institutions, like Russia or other countries in transition. For example, shortcomings in the Chinese legal system have made the Chinese international arbitration agency tne most active in the world in 1995. Similarly, where formal Russian legal institutions are often seen as rigid and difficult to use, skilled mediators or arbiters can often reach innovative solitions. A wcll-functioning ADR system can also exert competitive pressure on the formal courts of lawv. especially in commercial disputes. Given the poorI state of the formal judicial institutions in Russia and the resulting distrust of the citizenry in these institutions, ADR can be a welcome alternative with a potential to make an important contribution to strengthening the rule of law in Russia. Over the last several years, ADR has progressed in several sectors in Russia, including commercial arbitration among entrepreneurs, banks, insurance companies, and securities markets participants; and
 Section II. Institutional Setting 9 mediation of consumer and labor disputes. Currently, there are more than 300 private arbitration panels registered in Russia. Yet, ADR in Russia suffers from a variety of problems that can be addressed through technical assistance. Ignorance of the availability and advantages of ADR is widespread among the population and in many sectors of the economy. The legislative basis for ADR is not adequate; private arbitration functions on the basis of a 1992 provisional regulation. The limited number of specialists versed in ADR methodology impedes further growth of the sector. (For example, the Service for the Resolution of Labor Disputes of the Ministry of Labor routinely turns away requests for assistance due to the lack of qualified specialists.) Due to the relative novelty of the sector in Russia, ADR experts work in isolation and lack the basic means and infrastructure to exchange and disseminate views and information about their practice. The project will start addressing some of these shortcomings through financing: technical assistance in the preparation of a legislation covering ADR; training seminars for trainers in arbitration and mediation; public information campaigns on ADR; and support for annual meetings of specialists involved in ADR. 2.16 Project Implementation Agency. To carry out the proposed project, which cuts across so many institutions and areas, the Government has established the Russian FoundationforLegal Reform (RFLR). It will be responsible for implementing all components of the project. The founders of the RFLR are the Presidential Administration, the MOJ, the MOF, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Academy of Sciences of the Russian Federation. It is envisioned that the RFLR will continue to be active after project completion in the area of legal reform, receiving funds from budgetary sources, own legal expertise, and grants from other public or private donors. A detailed description of its structure and functions is contained in Part V of this report, as well as in Appendix M. 2.17 Other donor assistance for legal reform. In addition to Bank's assistance to Russia since 1991 in areas like banking, privatization, and natural resources law and regulations, Russia has received assistance from a number of countries and organizations. These are described in Appendix B and include support for specific pieces of legislation, training of officials and judges and programs to improve legislation. Russia has also received assistance in non-economic areas of legal reform, including criminal law improvements, jury trials, police training, electoral law assistance, and constitutional reforms. Private agencies and non-government organizations have supported individual aspects of law reform. Private agencies and non-government organizations have supported individual law school exchange programs and training of lawyers and bar associations. While support for criminal law reform and law enforcement is increasing among official agencies, direct assistance for economic law reform is decreasing rapidly due primarily to bilateral aid cutbacks set for 1996 and 1997. 2.18 The lessons which have been learned from other assistance provided in Russia for legal reform, including by the Bank, are several. First, government commitment is essential in order to effect change in the legal frarnework. Reform must therefore be owned by the government and not imposed from the outside. Second, since legal reform crosses governmental structures and branches, an overall reform program is needed as well as an institutional capacity to carry out such a program. Otherwise assistance will tend to be piecemeal and of limited impact. Third, there is both substantial lack of knowledge and skepticism in Russian society about the proper role of the legal system. Changes in the structures and institutions must be accompanied by changes in attitudes among the public and a willingness to use the legal system to defend individual economic rights. If successful, these changes will gradually lead to greater overall stability and predictability in economic activities and will lower transaction costs by providing a clearer and more comprehen.ive legal framework for the development of a market economy. To this end, the project will finance technical assistance in four areas of law which are expected to yield the following benefits: 6.2 Law drafting. The intended benefits of both components-the analytical studies as well as the direct assistance for drafting-are expedited drafting of an extremely broad legislative agenda, as well as improved quality of drafting. The economic benefits of such measures are difficult to measure, as the benefits of both are diffused throughout the economy in the form of lowered transaction costs. Lack of coordination and poor drafting imposes costs on the economy and reduces the effectiveness of government policies, as in the case of cost recovery in housing and maintenance services (see Box 6-1). The risks involved ill this activity are both non-project and project. Because legislative activity is obviously sensitive to tI.e overall policy environment for reform, both activities can be influenced by political events. In additioni, the specific component risk lies in the fact that better drafted laws do not necessarily lead to better laws passed tirougli the legislative process and/or better economic outcomes if adopted laws are not implerr.nted and enforced. The project seeks to address this risk through other components whic;h are intended to influence the implementation and enforcement of laws. 6.3 Legal information. The benefits of a well designed legal information system are difficult to define. It will undoubtedly lower many of the transaction costs that bedevil the Russian economy, but its scope is impossibl to foiesee at this poinit. Perhaps the benefit of the proposed feasibility study should be considered to be the savings from the cost of funds which might otherwise have been used in ad hoc incremental investments in the legal information system. In addition, there are less quantifiable, though equally real costs which might have been involved in the evolution of public-sector legal information systems which either crowd out or distort the market for private-sector provision of such services. There is some risk that following the feasibility study there may be no funds to carry out the creation of a full-fledged system, but the pilot/start-up investment envisioned as part of the feasibility study will be designed as a fully operational system which could be used on its own as well as part of a larger system.  36 Technical Annex: Russia Legal Reform Project Box 6-1: Legal drafting: the costs of lack of clarity In the context of Russian federalism, local authorities in Russia (municipalities, for the most part) have been given implementing authority in many areas of housing policy. One of these areas is cost recovery for the provision of housing maintenance and utility services, most of which are provided by municipal enterprises. The legacy of the Soviet period in this area included extremely low cost recovery for these services, such that in 1993 cost recovery from tenants in some cases fell to below 5 percent of the recurrent cost of providing these services. The federal Government has, in recent years, tried to create an enabling legislative framework to allow cities to increase cost recovery-key to cities' fiscal rationalization, as well as to more efficient provision of maintenance and utility services. This policy objective, however, was pursued via ad hoc government decrees as follows. Government decree 935 was issued in September 1993 and established an indicative framework for achieving cost recovery which suggested that tariff increases cover 20, 40, 60, 80, and 100 percent over the next five years such that cost recovery would be achieved in 1998. The increases themselves were indicative; cities were free to set their own pace. The binding target was 100 percent by 1998. This was not fully understood by local authorities, some of whom saw these intermediary increases as mandatory. As a result of the political outcry the Government issued decree 1329 in December 1993 to explain that cities were allowed to go at their own pace, taking local affordability issues into consideration. Not only by this stage had the Government paid the "cost' of issuing two decrees instead of one, the "cumulative' legal framework which emerged was now biased towards cities which might want to lag behind the federal guidelines. As federal Government officials became aware of the fact that some local authorities did not understand that they could exceed the 20-40-60-80-100 pace set by decree 935, in March 1995 the Government issued yet another decree. This last decree sought to reiterate that the guidelines established in the 935 decree were not binding by invalidating that specific section in decree 935; but the result in the localities was even greater confusion about the legal framework surrounding cost recovery for maintenance and utility services. The cost of this confusion was continued distortions of municipal budgets through subsidization of maintenance and utility services even as energy price increases increased actual costs, continuing drains on enterprises who had to provide subsidies to maintain and operate assets (housing) which in any case they were not entitled to own, and continued inefficient operation of maintenance and utility services-as well as the cost to the Government to keep revisiting this policy issue in their deliberations. five selected law schools. Many of the beneficiaries are in fact government entities, such as the ministries and agercies involved in legislative drafting or the courts. Some scope for cost recovery exists in components such as training, for example for ADR arbiters, but the institutional complexity of arranging for cost recovery are high. This is because the assistance is being carried out not through established institutions and channels, but through mechanisms created for this purpose, largely through the RFLR. 6.7 Institutional capacity of the RFLR is a key factor in implementation of this project. Risk attendant on the inadequate institutional capacity at the RFLR runs through all the components, to varying degrees. As discussed above, the RFLR was chosen as an implementing vehicle for the project because of the absence of any other one agency capable of cutting across all the areas involved in the four components, and because not all the principals involved in the components are equally open to carrying out activities which are designed to introduce reform. It is a newly created entity and subject to all the risks of a new agency, but simultaneously enjoys the benefits of being outside of the civil service (and therefore able to attract qualified specialists in an area where the differential between private and public sector pay is particularly high), and designed a priori to carry out project activities. Risks 6.8 There are substantial non-project risks that the consensus among government entities and branches may dissolve or that relations could become politicized to such a degree that the passage of laws could become difficult or delayed. This risk will be heightened by instability that may follow the presidential elections in June 1996. While support for legal reform is widespread in Russia, different parts of the government may have different areas of emphasis. There are also risks that implementation will be delayed by inadequate government coordination, especially if the role of the GGPU is changed or key personnel move. The project risks stem from the fact that many of the benefits sought under the project are dependent on a number of different factors, not all of which are addressed in the project. For instance, better drafts of laws resulting from the legal drafting component of the project can only lower transaction costs in the economy if they are properly implemented and enforced. The project seeks to mitigate some of these risks by trying to take a multifaceted approach to legal reform, by addressing issues of implementation and enforcement, and also by including different institutions within the project. As a result, the design is intended to allow other components to proceed (e.g. studies and training) even if some areas are affected by changes in government commitments (e.g. legislative drafting). Nonetheless, it must be recognized that particularly in a country as large and complex as Russia, the proposed project could be only a partial contribution to the extensive and long-term task of reforming the Russian legal system. While the risks of this project are considerable, they must be considered in the context of the much greater detrimental effect of not carrying out the proposed project and maintaining the status quo of the Russian legal system which does not meet the demands placed on a legal system in a functioning market environment. 6.9 At the same time the complexity of the project introduces implementation risks of its own. Experience to date in Russia with TA projects indicates that the outcome is heavily dependent on the quality of the implementing agency, and directly upon the quality of the staff at that agency. Many of the staff of the RFLR have held positions as senior civil servants involved in legal reform. Because the RFLR itself is a new institution, it is difficult to prejudge how it will perform its functions. These risks, however, are attendant on the vast majority of projects in Russia-to some extent they should be recognized as non-project risks. A transition economy such as Russia either has existing institutions which cannot be restructured to carry out the functions and tasks required of entities operating in a market

If new institutions have to be created-the risks are magnified by adding an institutional development aspect to almost every endeavor. Sustainability 6.10 The project seeks to introduce reforms in a number of areas where such reforms have not yet been attempted-public edlication in law, as well as innovation in legal education. There is some risk that these activities will not continue to be carried out following project completion. However, the project has been designed to focus on activities which contain within themselves the potential for further extending reforms-public education will include training of joumalists, judicial reform will address the training of trainers, and legal education activities will include the training of professors. To the extent that the project focuses on new activities-such as clinical courses in legal education or workshops for the judiciary-it is intended to demonstrate the potential benefits of such new activities. Sustainability of such activities will depend ultimately upon whether the constituents for such refonn-law schools which wish to establish themselves as centers of excellence, or judges who develop an understanding of the role of an independent judiciary-begin to make such objectives their own. Project design has sought to address such issues by, for instance, focusing the RFLR's work with law schools to a smaller number of institutions, or by assigning an educational consultant to each law school. Lastly, a program run through the American Bar Association has funded review of laws, twinning of law schools, workshops and support for bar associations and jury trials. With the exception of a new program dealing with crime prevention and criminal law, most of the larger USAID law programs, which have totalled over $40 million to date, will end in 1996 or taper off in 1997. The US government has actively cooperated with the Bank in preparation of the current Legal Reform Project and has funded several of the preparation studies which the government requested. In the future, the US intends to structure its continuing legal assistance programs in Russia, including support for criminal law reform, in a manner which complements, and does not overlap with the Bank-financed activities. (d) Netherlands: The Dutch government has actively assisted in the drafting of the new Russian Civil Code because of its own recent experience in revising its civil code. The Russian Federation (RF) is in the process of implementing a Legal Reform Project (Project). These terms of reference (TORs) refer to the latter objective and detail the consultants' services (Services) that will be required to meet this objective.' 2. Objective 3. Based on the above assessment, the Consultants shall issue specific recommendations on ways to improve such processes and agencies' institutional capacities, and be available for reasonable follow up discussions related to such a study and recommendations within and outside government organs. Services 4. The Russian constitution reserves certain areas to exclusive federal legislative jurisdiction; additional areas lie within the joint jurisdiction of the federal authorities and the 89 subjects of the Russian Federation. All other areas fall under the exclusive jurisdiction of the 89 subjects of the Russian Federation. The current constitutional, political and economic environment in Russia has led to an explosion of legislative and regulatory activity of the 89 subjects of the Russian Federation. Economic activities are increasingly affected and regulated by regional and local legislation, which does not (at least in theory) compete with, but complements, federal enactments. 2. The increasing need to generate more regional enactments, the novelty and urgency of this task at the regional level, as well as the complexity and diversity of subject matters that need to be covered, especially in the economic area, greatly affect the quality of such enactments. An additional element of complexity is the need to pay due attention to the constitutional balance between the federation and its subjects. During project preparation, it was determined that, in addition to the overall factors referred to above, there are at least three common impediments to effective legal drafting at the regional level: (a) weak institutional and technical capacity; (b) insufficient access to legal experts with specialized knowledge in economic areas; and (c) lack of financial resources. 3 . Two oblasts, Orel and Sverdlovsk, were selected by the federal authorities and have agreed to participate in the pilot program.' These regions were chosen on the basis of demonstrated willingness to push forward with legislative reforms in the area of private sector development. It was also determined that these regions are not recipients of high levels of foreign-financed technical assistance. 4. The Sverdlovsk oblast covers an area equivalent to the combined size of Austria, Belgium, Holland and Switzerland. It is located in the north central region of the Ural mountains and is inhabited by approximately 5 million people. More than 80 percent of the population lives in urban areas. The capital of the oblast is the city of Yekaterinburg, the third largest city in the Russian Federation. The oblast provides approximately 1/7 of the country's GNP. 5. The political structure of the oblast government is similar to the federal structure. There are three branches of oblast government: the executive, legislative, and judicial branches. The executive branch is represented by the oblast Government, headed by a chairman. Above and somewhat separate from the Government is the office of the Governor, who heads the oblast Administration. (This subdivision of executive authority is similar to the federal subdivision between the office of the President and the office of the Prime Minister who heads the Government of Russia). The legislative branch is represented by elected deputies who form the oblast Legislative Assembly, made up of two chambers. The judicial branch consists of district courts and one oblast court. (Pursuant to the Russian constitution and laws, the courts are part of the federal judiciary.) 1/ The cities of Moscow and St. Petersburg were excluded from consideration by the federal authorities on the grounds that these cities have unique access to expertise and know how in this area.

 2 Technical Annex: Russia Legal Reform Project Summary Description of the Composition and Size of the Court Systems of the Russian Federation There are three court systems in the Russian Federation (RF): (i) the Constitutional Court (one on the federal level; some republics, subjects of the RF, have separate constitutional courts); (ii) the courts of general jurisdiction (three instances, the highest of which is the Supreme Court of the RF); and (iii) the arbitrazh (commercial) courts (also three instances, the highest of which is the High Arbitrazh Court). Each system is organized and operated independently with separate funding sources and administrations. There is no unified or even similar structure for administering, operating, and financing the various courts. The Constitutional Court is directly funded from the federal budget and administered independently from the other courts. The High Arbitrazh Court receives a separate budgetary allocation for all the three instances of courts. The first two instances of courts of general jurisdiction are administratively and financially subordinate to the Ministry of Justice (MOJ); their budget is channelled through the MOJ. Their third instance, the Supreme Court of the RF, however, is funded directly from the federal budget and administered independently. This structure makes the arbitrazh courts (which are transformed from the former 'state arbitrazh' -- a quasi- judicial executive agency vested with resolving disputed among state-owned enterprises) fiscally better off and institutionally easier to administer and manage than the courts of general jurisdiction. Jurisdictional lines between the courts are laid out by the Constitution of the RF and are further elaborated in specific laws. There is, however, a substantial jurisdictional overlap between the general jurisdiction and arbitrazh court system in economic disputes. As mentioned, the system of courts of general jurisdiction is comprised of three levels, each of which has original jurisdiction over some cases. There are 2,500 trial courts manned by approximately 12,000 judges in the first instance courts, about 3,000 judges in the regional courts (second instance) and 116 judges employed by the Supreme Court. The vast majority of cases are heard in the district and cit courts (first instance), with approximately I % of cases reaching the regional and oblast (second instance) courts. Very few cases reach the Supreme Court, which exercises some original jurisdiction as do the middle level (regional and oblast) courts. The arbitrazh courts consist of much fewer courts and judges (their first instance courts are regional and oblast courts): 82 courts in the first instance (a total of 89, one in each of the subjects of the RF, are planned), 10 federal circuit courts in the second instance (with some original jurisdiction) and the High Arbitrazh Court. There are a total of 1,774 judges of which 1,578 are at the trial level, 143 in the circuit courts and 53 work in the High Arbitrazh Court. In addition to judges, the district and city courts of general jurisdiction employ judicial enforcement officers who work for both general jurisdiction and arbitrazh courts. These 9,500 enforcement officers, are tasked with executing judgments of both court systems.

 APPENDix K GUIDELINES FOR THE ORGANIZATION OF WORKSHOPS FOR JUDGES 1. International experience has demonstrated that the strongest resistance to reforming judicial systems around the world comes from the judges themselves. There are a number of reasons for that: first, perceived threat to their tenure; second, professional inertia; third, "rent-seeking" attitudes and habits; and fourth, cultural traditions concerning the role of a judge. Reforns usually do not succeed unless judges are involved in the process from the outset, feel that they own the reform process, and provide vital insider information on the problems in the adjudication system. The Workshop Concept 2. A series of judicial workshops are proposed as a device to involve judges in the reform process. These workshops are aimed at getting Russian judges to share their experiences and discuss problems in camera. These are not training seminars, but interactive fora where judges themselves will be working out solutions. The ultimate goals of the workshops are achieving consensus and leadership building (which are both central to judicial reform). The workshops are designed to involve judges of all three court systems (courts of general jurisdiction, arbitrazh courts and the Constitutional Court) and from all three instances. They will be organized in close cooperation with the Council of Judges of the RF which is the principal professional association of Russian judges of all different court systems. The Council, currently headed by a member of the Supreme Court of the RF, is interested and involved in issues of judicial reform in Russia. Objectives of Workshops 3. Immediate objectives of the workshops are: a) To gather information. How Russian judicial system operates in practice (its administrative structure, structure of specific courts, case management practices, budget allocations and flows, costs of justice for the litigants and invisible costs to the society, judicial training, legal procedures, ADR methods, and physical facilities and equipment), can only be learned from the judges themselves. b) To identify problems and hear proposals and solutions. No one is better equipped than judges to suggest realistic solutions to the problems they face every day. Usually they will have a good feeling of what would and would not work in practice. c) To motivate the judges. Giving the judges, who are often poorly paid and feel "forgotten" by their government, a voice in reform. This constitutes a great morale- booster, and reinforces pride in their job and satisfaction with their position. Moreover such workshops can begin to generate a sense of corporate identity, essential to the development of the judiciary as the third branch of government as envisioned in the Constitution of the Russian Federation. d) To identify potential leaders. Discussions during the workshops will reveal who understands the nature of the necessary changes and possesses leadership qualities among the judiciary.
 2 Technical Annex: Russia Legal Reform Project f) To encourage fraternity among judges. Informal setting will help the formation of "esprit de corps" among the Russian judiciary, especially given the nature of the different court systems in the RF. Methodology a) Speakers or facilitators can be the same for all the workshops (or all the sessions). Ten speakers are need for workshops; a maximum of three will be foreign judges/speakers. Most of them should be judges or former judges. Prior to the first workshops, a meeting of speakers will be held in order to explain the nature of the workshops, agree on written contributions, and emphasize to them that these presentations are not about the law or legal doctrines, but about the daily work of judges. b) Nature of the presentations. The role of the speakers is to introduce subjects for reflection and discussion, to raise questions and problems, and to encourage and stimulate debate and exchange of ideas among the participating judges. Presentations should not last more than half an hour. They are not supposed to refer to the substance of law or to legal doctrine, but rather to real life experiences. c) Participating judges. It is important that at least ten days before the workshops the participants receive and have the opportunity to review the reading materials prepared by the speakers. In workshops organized later, these materials should include reports from prior workshops. The judges should be ready when they return to their jurisdictions to share the experiences of the workshops in presentations, speeches, lectures, articles, and papers. d) Duration of the workshops. The workshops will take three days for each participating judge. Three sets of workshops (each lasting three days) will take place during the same week, staggered by a day. e) Venue. The workshops should be held in a resort outside of a large city in order to create a collegial atmosphere and give the judges an opportunity to interact with one another. f) Evaluation and Reports. At the end of each workshop, participating judges will make anonymous evaluations of the program, the speakers, the reading materials, the discussions, the organization, and the conclusions. These evaluations, together with the records of the workshop proceedings will be factored into the preparation of a final report of each of the workshops. Conclusions and recommendations of the workshops will be distributed, in consultation with the Council of Judges and the RFLR, to the judiciary. This distribution can be in the form of a newsletter of the Council of Judges. Also, judges participating in later organized workshops should familiarize themselves with reports from prior workshops.

doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Legal Reform Project is to improve the performance of the Russian legal system in areas key to the effective functioning of market institutions. Specific objectives are to: 1) improve the quality of drafting of economic laws, decrees and regulations; 2) assist the government of Russia in designing the appropriate classification of legislation (including in electronic format) and in identifying the appropriate methods of codifying Russian legislation; 3) begin to introduce innovative teaching methods and materials in the legal education system, with particular emphasis on increased exchange between legal academia and practice and to improve teacher training; and 4) improve the quality of judicial training for courts of general jurisdiction and arbitrage courts. The project will comprise four inter-related components consisting of technical assistance to support: 1) legal drafting; 2) collection and dissemination of legal information; 3) legal education, including public education campaigns; and 4) judicial reform, including support for alternative dispute resolution.
